title: 113_hr3565
content: The Act titled "Biennial Commission on Energy Policy Act of 2013" amends the Department of Energy Organization Act by introducing a new section establishing the Biennial Commission on Energy Policy. The Biennial Commission on Energy Policy, established by the Act of 2013, consists of 15 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, minority leader of the House, majority leader of the Senate, and minority leader of the Senate. Members must be appointed within 30 days of the Commission's establishment. Members of the Biennial Commission on Energy Policy are appointed within 30 days of the 114th Congress's first session. They serve a 2-year term and must consult with the President and specified Members of Congress to ensure diversity in expertise. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Qualifications are required for each member appointed. The Biennial Commission on Energy Policy members must have professional experience in various areas such as governmental service, energy production, renewable energy resource development, energy law, public administration, fossil fuel production, energy efficiency, environmental policy, labor, workplace safety, commerce and trade, corporate policies, infrastructure, and foreign affairs. Additionally, no more than 8 members can be affiliated with the same political party. The Commission members must have professional experience in various areas such as energy production, renewable energy, energy law, and environmental policy. No government employees can serve on the Commission, and members will receive compensation and travel expenses. The Commission, established under subchapter I of chapter 57 of title 5, United States Code, must have members with professional experience in energy-related fields. The Commission will meet within 30 days of all members being appointed, with a chairperson and vice chairperson selected by the members. Subcommittees may be created by majority vote for specific duties, with six members needed for a quorum. Meetings will be called by the chairperson after the initial meeting. The Commission will meet upon the call of the chairperson or a majority of its members. Quarterly stakeholder meetings will be held to assist the Commission in its duties, with members encouraged to attend either in person or via teleconference. "SEC. 802. Duties and powers of the Commission." The Commission is tasked with analyzing and evaluating various energy sources in the US, assessing policy options to increase energy supplies and efficiency, and examining energy storage and distribution requirements, including intermittent sources. The Commission will analyze stakeholders' roles in creating an integrated energy policy, assess energy programs' effectiveness, make recommendations for executive branch organization changes, and study relevant matters. The Commission will study relevant matters raised at stakeholder meetings and review materials on energy, including laws, regulations, policies, programs, scientific literature, and studies conducted by other entities. Reports on progress are due by July 1. The Commission is required to submit progress reports to Congress on its activities and information gathered every first and third year of each Presidential term. Additionally, reports with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislative and administrative actions are due every second and fourth year of each term. These reports must be made publicly available via a website. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, administer oaths, create subcommittees with similar powers, accept gifts, and use postal services. The Commission has the authority to contract with government and private agencies, obtain official data from federal departments and agencies, and receive necessary information to carry out its duties. The Commission has the authority to contract with government and private agencies, obtain official data from federal departments and agencies, and receive necessary information to carry out its duties. Personnel matters are addressed in SEC. 803. The chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and up to five staff members without following standard appointment procedures. The compensation for these positions can be determined by the chairperson without adhering to standard pay regulations, with a salary cap set at the level V of the Executive Schedule. Additionally, the head of any department or agency may detail government employees to assist the Commission upon request. The chairperson of the Commission can appoint an executive director and staff members without standard procedures. Government personnel can be detailed to assist the Commission. The chairperson can also procure temporary services at specified rates. SEC. 804 authorizes $3,000,000 for the Secretary of Energy without fiscal year limitation. Table of Contents amendments include sections 801, 802, 803, and 804. The effective date for the amendments is the first day of the 114th Congress.
